teacherResources.title: A Terrain of Trust
teacherResources.shortDesc: In this episode, A Terrain of Trust, Anne and Steve are joined by Brandy Monk-Payton, Assistant Professor of Communication and Media Studies at Fordham University who shares her thoughts about representation, collaboration and effective instruction.

teacherResources.title: Diversity, Equity and Inclusion
teacherResources.shortDesc: In this episode, Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Anne and Steve are joined by Kendra Dunbar, Assistant Director for Equity and Inclusion at Fordham University who shares her thoughts about trauma and being supportive and engaged members of our University and classroom communities.

exercises.title: Motion Capture
exercises.shortDesc: Black expression through motion capture with creative technologist LaJune MacMillian.
exercises.longDesc: **The Black Movement Project (BMP)** is a library for activists, performers & artists to create diverse XR projects, a space to research how and why we move, and an archive of Black existence. BMP seeks to grow community through the use of performances, XR experiences, workshops, conversations, and tool making. BMP incorporates a narrative component to be seen as both a live performance and movement portrait showing how Black movement has been used as a tool for the preservation of Black culture as well as a vehicle of self-evolution. This portrait follows the Movement journey of Nala Duma, a music producer, dancer, and artist living in NYC.

learnContent.text: **The Black Movement Project (BMP)** is a library for activists, performers & artists to create diverse XR projects, a space to research how and why we move, and an archive of Black existence. BMP seeks to grow community through the use of performances, XR experiences, workshops, conversations, and tool making. BMP incorporates a narrative component to be seen as both a live performance and movement portrait showing how Black movement has been used as a tool for the preservation of Black culture as well as a vehicle of self-evolution. This portrait follows the Movement journey of Nala Duma, a music producer, dancer, and artist living in NYC.

This class is co-presented by Pioneer Works and the New York Public Library, and is part of a series of classes and tutorials offered in conjunction with NYPL’s Tech Kits for Performing Artists program. In this example, participants will create their first basic Augmented Reality project using Web XR. This workshop will also provide an introduction to avatar and motion capture creation using [Deepmotion](https://www.deepmotion.com/). No prior experience with these tools are needed.

### Materials you will need:

1. [ ] Camera to capture digital photo/videos
2. [ ] Computer to run Deep Motion software

### Steps:

**Step 1: Capture video**

Consider a cultural movement you feel is perhaps not reflected in popular media (games, videos, tv shows, movies, etc). For instance, it can be a cultural mannerism like moving your hands in a certain way to convey a certain mood or message. Or it could be a dance movement that is not commonly known.

3. [ ] Take a picture of yourself looking directly at the camera
4. [ ] Record a 10 seconds (or less) video of this movement or gesture. Be sure to take a full shot - your whole body.

**Step 2: Prepare media for use**

Upload on to your computer. If you are using a webcam this step will probably not be necessary.

**Step 3: Upload into Deep Motion software**

Go to DeepMotion online and use the software to create an avatar that will animate based on the video your recorded.

5. Open DeepMotion software (deepmotion.com) and sign up for an account.
6. Go to Animate 3D and hit Create.
7. Use one of the default character OR use the ReadyPlayerMe character creation tool - and edit as you see fit. Note: you can upload the photo you took earlier to generate a base character to work from if you want.
8. Name your character and you are done creating your character.
9. Then click on create animation, and upload the video into the software. The video needs to have a resolution of 1920 x 1080 or lower, AND be less than 10 seconds. So you may have to edit the video.
10. Upload your video into the software.
11. Download the GLB file.

**Step 4: Open the GLB file**

1. Use gltf-viewer to open your GLB file. https://gltf-viewer.donmccurdy.com/

**Step 5: Prepare a reflection statement.**

In 500 words or less, prepare a statement that addresses the following questions:

- What was the most challenging aspect of this exercise?
- What kind of cultural expressions did you attempt to capture?
- What do you think are the limitations of these tools in terms of capturing embodied cultural expressions and movements?

exercises.title: Facial Recognition
exercises.shortDesc: The Gender Shades Project pilots an intersectional approach to inclusive product testing for AI.
exercises.longDesc: The Gender Shades Project pilots an intersectional approach to inclusive product testing for AI. Gender Shades is a preliminary excavation of inadvertent negligence that will cripple the age of automation and further exacerbate inequality if left to fester. The deeper we dig, the more remnants of bias we will find in our technology. We cannot afford to look away this time, because the stakes are simply too high.  We risk losing the gains made with the civil rights movement and women's movement under the false assumption of machine neutrality. Automated systems are not inherently neutral. They reflect the priorities, preferences, and prejudices—the coded gaze—of those who have the power to mold artificial intelligence.

learnContent.text: The Gender Shades Project pilots an intersectional approach to inclusive product testing for AI. Gender Shades is a preliminary excavation of inadvertent negligence that will cripple the age of automation and further exacerbate inequality if left to fester. The deeper we dig, the more remnants of bias we will find in our technology. We cannot afford to look away this time, because the stakes are simply too high.  We risk losing the gains made with the civil rights movement and women's movement under the false assumption of machine neutrality. Automated systems are not inherently neutral. They reflect the priorities, preferences, and prejudices—the coded gaze—of those who have the power to mold artificial intelligence.
learnContent.credit: Credit: Joy Buolamwini and Jimmy Day

This workshop will also provide an introduction to avatar and motion capture creation using [Deepmotion](https://www.deepmotion.com/). No prior experience with these tools are needed.

Upload on to your computer. If you are using a webcam this step will probably not be necessary.

5. Open DeepMotion software (deepmotion.com) and sign up for an account.

9. Then click on create animation, and upload the video into the software. The video needs to have a resolution of 1920 x 1080 or lower, AND be less than 10 seconds. So you may have to edit the video.
10. Upload your video into the software.
11. Download the GLB file.

1. Use gltf-viewer to open your GLB file. https://gltf-viewer.donmccurdy.com/

**Step 5: Prepare a reflection statement.**

In 500 words or less, prepare a statement that addresses the following questions:

- What was the most challenging aspect of this exercise?
- What kind of cultural expressions did you attempt to capture?
- What do you think are the limitations of these tools in terms of capturing embodied cultural expressions and movements?
